message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sagging of the left pelvis when the right leg is weight-bearing suggests that the right superior gluteal nerve is likely to have been injured. This nerve innervates the gluteus medius muscle, which helps to maintain a level pelvis when weight-bearing on one leg. None of the other options innervate this muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sagging of the left pelvis when the right leg is weight-bearing is suggestive of weakness in the right gluteus medius muscle, which is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. Among the options, only the right superior gluteal nerve is responsible for the innervation of the gluteus medius muscle on the same side. Therefore, the most likely nerve to have been injured in this patient is the right superior gluteal nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sagging of the left pelvis when the right leg is weight-bearing suggests a weakness of the right superior gluteal muscle. This muscle is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve, which arises from the L4-S1 nerve roots. Among the options, only the right superior gluteal nerve innervates this muscle, making it the most likely nerve to have been injured during the hip replacement surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sagging of the left pelvis when the right leg is weight-bearing suggests that the right gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles are not functioning properly, indicating an injury to the right superior gluteal nerve. The femoral nerves innervate the quadriceps muscles and are not likely to be involved in this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s sagging of the left pelvis suggests weakness of the left gluteus medius muscle, which is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. Among the options, only the right superior gluteal nerve innervates the right gluteus medius muscle, which can cause left-sided hip sagging when the right leg is weight-bearing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sagging of the left pelvis indicates weakness of the left gluteus medius. The superior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus medius muscle, and it arises from the sacral plexus. Therefore, as the right leg bears weight, the pelvis tilts towards the unsupported left side. The right superior gluteal nerve is most likely to have been injured during the hip replacement surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sagging of the left pelvis when her right leg is weight-bearing suggests weakness of the right hip abductors, which are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. Among the options, only the right superior gluteal nerve is responsible for the hip abductors on the affected side.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sagging of the left pelvis suggests a trendelenburg gait, which is caused by weakness of the hip abductor muscles. The superior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, and the femoral nerve supplies the quadriceps muscles. Among the options, only the right superior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus medius muscle that maintains hip stability on the opposite side during weight-bearing. Thus, if it is injured, it can lead to the characteristic trendelenburg gait seen in the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sagging of the left pelvis when the right leg is weight-bearing indicates a weakness in the right hip abductors, which are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. Among the given options, only the right superior gluteal nerve innervates the hip abductors on the affected side, making it most likely to have been injured during surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sagging of the left pelvis when the right leg is weight-bearing suggests weakness of the muscles innervated by the right superior gluteal nerve. This nerve is commonly affected during total hip replacement surgery.
